age: 48. gender: F.  
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___

RUQ pain 
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ with a h/o cholelithiasis, HTN, 
___ tear, C-section, hysterectomy and suicidal 
ideation who initially presented to ___ for RUQ 
pain with US and MRCP findings of CBD dilation of ~8mm, 
transferred to ___ for potential EUS vs ERCP. 

Pt was in her usual state of health until 2 weeks prior to 
presentation when she experienced sudden onset RUQ pain and 
nausea following a meal at a ___ restaurant. Pt reports US 
notable for gallstones at the time, treated conservatively. She 
was scheduled to receive an elective CCY at ___ with Dr. ___) on ___. 
However, one week later she experienced recurrent RUQ pain and 
presented to ___ on ___. She reports that the pain was 
so severe that she had active suicidal ideation and thoughts of 
hurting herself with a knife. She adds that she experienced
auditory hallucinations that encouraged self-harm. At ___, 
___ US notable for CBD dilatation of 8 mm with no gallbladder 
wall thickening or pericholecystitic fluid. MRCP confirmed 
dilated CBD 7-8mm with motion artifact. HIDA scan with CCK 
stimulation demonstrated EF 80.5% and normal filling from
gallbladder to the small bowel, though increased transient time 
to small bowel greater than 2.5 hours. At ___, pt's WBC and 
LFTs were wnl. She was symptomatically treated with oxycodone 
prn and zofran prn. 

Of note, pt was placed on ___ at ___ for SI ___ RUQ 
pain. Pt reports thoughts of self-harm with plan to apply "a 
knife to her throat". Pt was started on risperidone which she 
reports has eliminated her auditory hallucinations. 

Following arrival to floor, pt continued to report RUQ pain 
rated as a ___ with radiation to back and L shoulder.  

 
Past Medical History:
PMH: HTN, ___ tear, ?calcified heart valve per pt

PSH: C-section (per transfer records), total laparoscopic
hysterectomy 

Psychiatric Hx: PTSD, anxiety, SI following mother's death last
year with plan to "jump in front of car", history of bulimia. 
Per
___, pt has previously been in ___.

___

No known psychiatric illness or suicide attempts. Father and 
both grandfathers with alcohol abuse.

Psych: Denies SI and auditory/visual/tactile hallucinosis at

Imaging:

___ - ___ ___: Uploaded to ___, please see full report.
Summary of pertinent findings: Multiple gallstones in
gallbladder. No gallbladder wall thickening or pericholecystic
fluid. Sonographic ___ sign is reported positive by
sonographer. Proximal common bile duct measures 8mm in diameter.
No common duct stone visualized. 

MRCP - ___ ___: Uploaded to ___, please see full
report. Summary of pertinent findings: Tiny filling defects in
the neck of gallbladder suggesting gallstones. No 
pericholecystic
edema or fluid. Common bile duct measures approximately 7-8mm. 
No
intrahepatic bile duct dilatation. Pancreatic duct is normal in
caliber. No intraluminal filling defects are seen within the 
bile
ducts. Slightly limited study due to motion artifact. 

HIDA with CCK- ___ ___: Uploaded to ___, please see
full report. Summary of pertinent findings: Normal visualization
of liver, common bile duct, gallbladder and small bowel, 
although
of note, the small bowel is visualized after 2.5 hours. No
defects of uptake are seen within liver. Calculated gallbladder
ejection fraction is 80.5%. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ y/o F with a h/o cholelithiasis, HTN, ___ 
___ tear, C-section, hysterectomy and suicidal ideation who 
initially presented to ___ for RUQ pain with US 
and MRCP findings of CBD dilation of ~8mm, transferred to ___ 
for potential EUS vs ERCP. The patient was admitted to the Acute 
Care Surgery service for further medical care.  

On HD1, Psychiatry was consulted for evaluation and management 
of SI while inpatient.  The patient was placed under ___, 
and 1:1 observation was provided given recent SI and possibility 
for exacerbation of mood with ongoing stressors and 
hospitalization. 

On HD1, the patient was taken to the operating room and 
underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy.  The patient tolerated 
this procedure well (reader, please refer to Operative Notes for 
further details).  After remaining hemodynamically stable in the 
PACU, the patient was transferred to the surgical floor. 

On POD1, the patient was written for a regular diet, her IV 
fluid were discontinued and she was started on oral pain 
medication.  Her foley catheter was removed and she voided 
without issue. On POD 2, psychiatry revisit the patient and were 
okay with discontinuing 1:1 and recommended continuing all her 
home psych medications,

During this hospitalization, the patient ambulated early and 
frequently, was adherent with respiratory toilet and incentive 
spirometry, and actively participated in the plan of care. The 
patient received subcutaneous heparin and venodyne boots were 
used during this stay. 

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a regular 
diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient was discharged to an inpatient 
psychiatric facility. The patient received discharge teaching 
and follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and 
agreement with the discharge plan.

 
 
Medications on Admission:
- Trazodone 150 mg qHS
- Clonazepam 0.5 mg PO TID 
- Risperidone 2mg PO qHS
- Amlodipine 10 mg PO daily AM
- Lamotrigine 150 mg PO BID 
- Estrogens (Premarin) 1.25 mg PO daily 
- Diphenhydramine 50 mg PO qHS
- Mitrazapine 15 mg qHS
- Ondansetron 4mg q8h (changed by ___ to q6h)
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain - Mild  
2.  Cepacol (Sore Throat Lozenge) 2 LOZ PO Q4H:PRN Sore throat  
3.  Chloraseptic Throat Spray 1 SPRY PO Q6H:PRN sore throat  
4.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID  
5.  OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain - 
Moderate 
Take 1 tablet every 4 hours when severe pain not controlled with 
tylenol 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth Q4H:PRN Disp #*20 Tablet 
Refills:*0 
6.  Senna 8.6 mg PO BID:PRN contripation  
7.  amLODIPine 10 mg PO DAILY  
8.  ClonazePAM 0.5 mg PO TID  
9.  Estrogens Conjugated 1.25 mg PO DAILY  
10.  LamoTRIgine 150 mg PO BID  
11.  Mirtazapine 15 mg PO QHS  
12.  Pantoprazole 40 mg PO Q12H  
13.  RisperiDONE 0.5 mg PO BID  
14.  RisperiDONE 2 mg PO QHS  
15.  TraZODone 150 mg PO QHS  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Acute cholecystitis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

It was a pleasure caring for you at the ___ 
___.  You were admitted to the Acute Care Surgery 
service with acute cholecystitis (gallbladder inflammation) and 
were taken to the operating room and had your gallbladder 
removed laparoscopically.  This procedure went well.  Your pain 
is better controlled and you are now tolerating a regular diet. 

The Psychiatry service met with you given your thoughts of 
self-harm, and have recommended that you be discharged to a 
Psychiatric facility for further mental health care.  

You are now medically cleared to be discharged from the 
hospital. Please note the following discharge instructions:

Please follow up in the Acute Care Surgery clinic at the 
appointment listed below.
 
ACTIVITY:
 
o Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and 
feel you could respond in an emergency.
o You may climb stairs. 
o  You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until 
you see your surgeon at your next visit.
o  Don't lift more than ___ lbs for 4 weeks. (This is about 
the weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies 
to lifting children, but they may sit on your lap.
o You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable.
o You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a 
time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when you 
can resume tub baths or swimming.
 
HOW YOU MAY FEEL: 
o  You may feel weak or "washed out" for a couple of weeks. You 
might want to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you.
o  You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your 
throat during surgery.
o  You might have trouble concentrating or difficulty sleeping. 
You might feel somewhat depressed.
o  You could have a poor appetite for a while. Food may seem 
unappealing.
o  All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go 
away in a short time.  If they do not, tell your surgeon.
 
YOUR INCISION:
o Tomorrow you may shower and remove the gauzes over your 
incisions. Under these dressing you have small plastic bandages 
called steri-strips. Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks. 
(These are the thin paper strips that might be on your 
incision.) But if they fall off before that that's okay).
o Your incisions may be slightly red around the stitches. This 
is normal.
o You may gently wash away dried material around your incision.
o Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area.
o Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told 
otherwise.
o You may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid 
staining your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe, 
please call your surgeon.
o You may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when you may 
resume tub baths or swimming.
 
YOUR BOWELS:
o Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain 
medications. If needed, you may take a stool softener (such as 
Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of 
magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these 
medicines without a prescription.
o If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain 
moving the bowels, call your surgeon. 
 
PAIN MANAGEMENT:
o It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal 
surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness". 
o Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain 
is getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.
o You will receive a prescription for pain medicine to take by 
mouth. It is important to take this medicine as directed. o Do 
not take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take more 
medicine at one time than prescribed.
o Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your 
pain gets too severe.
o Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take 
prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain 
medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your 
surgeon has said its okay.
o If you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of 
pain medicine.
o Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when you 
cough or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises.
If you experience any of the following, please contact your 
surgeon:
- sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours
- pain that is getting worse over time
- pain accompanied by fever of more than 101
- a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain
 
MEDICATIONS:
Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as 
you did before, unless you have been told differently.
If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to 
take, please call your surgeon.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

||startoftext||The patient is a 48-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of RUQ pain. She has a history of cholelithiasis, hypertension, and a tear, as well as a C-section and hysterectomy. She also has a history of suicidal ideation and has previously been in therapy for PTSD, anxiety, and suicidal ideation following her mother's death. 

The patient underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy and was started on oral pain medication. She was also prescribed risperidone to manage her auditory hallucinations. At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile with stable vital signs, and was tolerating a regular diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well controlled. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo M with unknown PMH presented s/p cardiac arrest, with

Coronary artery disease
     -s/p cardiac cath: 60% mid and distal LAD, chronic toatl 
mid distal L ___ occlusion of the OM1, RCA small and

     -s/p drug coated stent to the OM1
-presumed ventricular arrythmia

Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted this hospitalization following a cardiac 
arrest. You underwent a cooling of your body temperature to help 
decrease any negative effects on the brain following cardiac 
arrest. The likely cause of your arrest is an arrythmia as a 
result of scarring from coronary artery disease. 

In order to assess the perfusion of the heart by the coronary 
arteries you underwent a cardiac catheterization which revealed 
multiple blockages in the conroary arteries. We were able to 
place a stent in one of the arteries; the obtuse marginal branch 
of the left circumflex artery that feeds the side portion of the 
heart muscle.

At the time of your cardiac arrest your heart pupming function 
was depressed. A most recent echocardiogram revealed that the 
pumping function has greatly improved since the time of your 
arrest.

You have been started on the following new medications:
Aspirin 81 mg daily: this is taken to decrease clot in the 
coronary arteries

Atorvastatin 80mg daily: this is a cholesterol medication taken 
to decrease worsening of plaque formation.

Lisinopril 5mg daily: this decreases the resistance the heart 
has to pump against and thereby decreased the blood pressure

Metoprolol XL 100mg daily: this medication decresases the 
workload of the heart by decreasing the heart rate and thereby 
the blood pressure

Ticagelor 90mg two times a day: This medication decreases the 
risk of clot formation where the stent was placed. 

KCL 20meq daily: you have required Potaassium daily since your 
admission. You should take this daily and then have labs checked 
on ___ by visiting nursing to assess your response. 

PLEASE CONTINUE:
Metformin 100mg XL twice a day for your diabetes
Sertraline 200mg daily for depression
Levothyroxeine 50mcg daily
 
PLEASE HOLD until seen by your PCP/Cardiologist:
Wellbutrin
Mirtazapine

****Failure to take the Ticagelor and the aspirin could result 
in a lifethreatening heart attack**** 

You have been set up with a Lifevest. The details of this device 
have been discussed with you. If you go into a lifethreatening 
arrythmia again, this device will detect that arrythmia and 
deliver an electric shock to return you to a normal sinus 
rythym. The plan is for you to eventually receieve an internal 
cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) in the future once your heart 
has been given time to recover from your recent cardiac arrest. 
This will be discussed in follow up with the electrophysiology 
team as an outpatient.

You should avoid stressful situations and exercise while you are 
wearing the lifevest. You also CANNOT drive with the lifevest. 
You may participate in your reguilar activities including 
walking as long as this does not cause you physical strain.  
  
You will need a variety of follow up appointments as detailed 
below.

You will need labs in 6 weeks to assess your liver function and 
cholesterol panel since we increased your statin or cholesterol 
medication.  You will also need your electrolytes and your 
kidney function checked on ___ as we have started 
you on a medication called Lisinopril and a potassium 
supplement. 

Today we discussed heart failure and the need to weigh yourself 
every day before breakfast as well as the improtance of 
following a low salt diet. If your weight goes up by more than 3 
lbs in 2 days you should call Dr. ___ cardiologist). 

If you have any questions or concerns related to your symptoms 
or your hospitalization you can call the heartline which has 
been given to you with your discharge paperwork. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

||startoftext||The patient is a 47-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital after experiencing a cardiac arrest. He was found to have severe 2-vessel coronary artery disease, with chronic total occlusion of the left circumflex artery and occlusion of the OM1 branch. He underwent a percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with a drug-eluting stent (DES) in the OM1 branch. His past medical history includes diabetes, dyslipidemia, hypertension, depression, sleep apnea, and hypothyroidism. He has no known allergies or adverse reactions.

The patient's diagnosis includes moderate-severe regional and global systolic dysfunction due to coronary artery disease, mild global right ventricular systolic dysfunction, and mild mitral regurgitation. He was treated with aspirin, ticagrelor, and atorvastatin, and was also prescribed metoprolol and lisinopril.

The patient's medications at discharge include levothyroxine, sertraline, aspirin, atorvastatin, and metoprolol. ||endoftext||

since your lung surgery for talc pleurodesis. The talc 
intrapleural injection was effective as your air leak has 
resolved and your chest xray shows almost full expansion of the

target: ||startoftext||The patient is a 50-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with a prolonged air leak following a right thoracotomy and wedge resection for metastatic sarcoma. She had a history of Hodgkin's lymphoma, breast cancer, asthma, hypothyroidism, osteoarthritis, and allergies to Percocet, Vicodin, and Hydromorphone. She was diagnosed with a prolonged air leak post-right thoracotomy with multiple wedge resections. The patient underwent a right pleural talc pleurodesis procedure and was prescribed medications including acetaminophen, albuterol, biotin, calcium, cetirizine, glucosamine-chondroitin, Levothyroxine, and lorazepam. She was discharged home with instructions to follow up with her doctor in two weeks and to monitor her incisions for any signs of infection or increased redness. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ with PMH of T2DM, CKD, HTN, focal motor 
status epilepticus for which he was admitted in ___, 
history of TIAs considered ASA failure and started on Plavix, 
idiopathic thrombocytopenic purupura, who presented to ___ 
earlier today with 2 days of worsening inability to tolerate 
secretions, "hot potato voice," and fevers in the setting of 
having had a sore throat for the past 1 week. 

On presentation to the ED he was found to have a swollen 
inferior soft palate, left-sided neck swelling, a marbled voice, 
and inability to swallow secretions. A CT neck was obtained 
which showed sialolithiasis with sialadenitis of the L 
submandibular gland and no drainable fluid collection. The 
airway appeared patent, and based on clinical findings by the ED 
team he was felt to most likely have Ludwig's angina and was 
given decadron and Unasyn.  He was admitted to the TSICU under 
the intensivist service.  

In the TSICU, the patient appeared well with no difficulty 
controlling secretions or protecting his airway; per daughter at 
bedside the patient improved significantly after receiving IV 
dexamethasone and IV unasyn in the ED. OMFS and ENT were 
contacted, and they confirmed that the patient has sialithiasis 
and sialadenitis; no Ludwig's Angina and no operative 
indication. Per their recommendations, he was continued on 
Unasyn and daily dexamethasone, and was given sialogogues for 
his sialithiasis. On tele he was noticed to have possible first 
degree block with dropped ventricular beats, EP consulted for 
concern for AV block, which subsequently revealed itself to be a 
Mobitz 1. Later became 2:1, asymptomatic and maintaining BPs but 
with episodes of bradycardia to ___ overnight for which he was 
kept in the ICU. Also of note, while NPO for airway watch, he 
was given IV conversions of home keppra and phenytoin and 
clobazam was transitioned to IV Ativan which was actually held 
due to bradycardia. He had no seizure-like activity during this 
admission.

He continued to do well into the morning of ___. He was 
restarted on PO home medications and tolerated a regular diet. 
He had no issues with airway or respirations. Per OMFS he was 
started on augmentin ___nd peridex and cleared for 
discharge home from their perspective. Cardiology also saw the 
patient in regards to his suspected AV block and felt that he 
had no indications for intervention or medication adjustment.  
He was thus discharged home from the TSICU with detailed 
discharge instructions and outpatient follow-up in place.

Discharge Diagnosis:
sialadenitis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted tot he ___ ICU to monitor your airway it he 
setting of an infection of your salivary glands.  You are now 
safe to be sent home and will follow up with your doctor as 
described below.

What is sialadenitis?
Sialadenitis is an infection (viral or bacterial) or 
inflammation
of the salivary glands. Sialadenitis
can occur in the parotid, submandibular or sublingual glands.
A person with sialadenitis may have the following symptoms:
 Pain & swelling around the cheek, jaw or mouth
 Fever or chills
 Pus in the mouth
 Trouble opening the mouth or swallowing
 Dry mouth
 Visible stones in the mouth or a gritty feeling
How do I manage sialadenitis?
 Drink plenty of water.
 Encourage salivation - this can be assisted by eating sour 
hard
candy or other sour food
or drink.
 You may need to take an over the counter analgesic to treat 
the
pain (e.g. Paracetamol,
Ibuprofen)
 You may require oral antibiotics that will be prescribed by
your doctor. Occasionally you
may require antibiotics in your vein
 Gently massage the skin over the affected gland
 Warm moist towel or wash cloth compress onto the skin over the
area for ___ mins,
every few hours.

Follow up appointment: ___ at 10am, 
___ ___ ___ floor) at ___. You
will be seeing Dr ___. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___
target:
||startoftext||The patient is a 64-year-old male who was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) due to an inability to tolerate secretions, "hot potato voice," and fevers. He has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes, chronic kidney disease, hypertension, and idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura. He was diagnosed with sialolithiasis with sialadenitis of the left submandibular gland and was treated with decadron and Unasyn. He was also found to have a possible first-degree block with dropped ventricular beats, which was later confirmed to be a Mobitz 1 block.

The patient's medications at admission included amlodipine, clobazam, Plavix, HCTZ, insulin degludec, Keppra, lisinopril, metformin, phenytoin, sitagliptin, tamsulosin, and Viagra. At discharge, he was prescribed amoxicillin-clavulanic acid, chlorhexidine gluconate oral rinse, sildenafil, amlodipine, clobazam, clopidogrel, dorzolamide, econazole, hydrochlorothiazide, latanoprost, levETIRAcetam, lisinopril, metformin, phenytoin, sitagliptin, tamsulosin, and insulin degludec.

The patient was discharged home with instructions to follow up with his doctor and to continue taking his medications as prescribed. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ woman who initially presented 
with severe abdominal pain. At that time, no obvious findings on 
CT scan and no obvious leak was appreciated. Given her pain and 
significant CT findings, it was decided that she would benefit 
from a diagnostic laparoscopy. At that time, I was concerned 
that she may actually have a gastric perforation and may have a 
gallbladder issue that could potentially be addressed 
laparoscopically. Thus, we decided to start the case 
laparoscopically with potential conversion to an open procedure 
if a significant
lesion in the stomach was appreciated. The risks and benefits of 
the procedure were described in detail to the patient. Despite 
these risks, she chose to proceed with surgery. She was found to 
have a gastric perforation and therefore converted to 
exploratory laparotomy with ___ patch and placement of a 
Pravena vac.

hospitalization; pain was initially managed with a IV dialudid 
PCA and then transitioned to oral acetaminophen and oxycodone 
once tolerating a diet.

standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored.
Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Good pulmonary 
toilet, early ambulation and incentive spirometry were 
encouraged throughout hospitalization.

___ tube in place for decompression and nasojejunal 
tube in place for feeding.  On POD2 tube feeding were started 
through the doboff. On POD3 the NGT was accidently  removed by 
the patient when sneezing. She was kept NPO (except tube feeds). 
On POD5 she underwent upper GI leak test that was unclear and 
therefore was repeated on POD7 and negative for leak. Doboff was 
removed and she was given a regular diet with good tolerability. 
H.Pylori result was positive and therefore she was started on 
quadruple therapy once tolerating a diet.

infection, of which there were none. H.Pylori quadrupal therapy 
started and prescribed 2 week course.

of bleeding, of which there were none.

dyne boots were used during this stay and was encouraged to get 
up and ambulate as early as possible.

and hemodynamically stable.  The patient was tolerating a diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient received discharge teaching and 
follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and

Mental Status: Clear and coherent.

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___, 

You were admitted to the hospital because you had abdominal 
pain. You had a CT scan which showed that you had a perforation 
in your stomach where it connects to your small intestine. It 
was found to be caused by an infection (H.pylori), for which you 
have been started on medication and will finish after discharge. 
You underwent surgery to get your perforation fixed. You have 
tolerated a regular diet, had a return of bowel function, and 
your pain has been well-controlled. Thus, you are now ready to 
be discharged home to continue your recovery. Please follow the 
discharge instructions below: 

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.
Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

Incision Care:
*Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner if you have 
increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the incision 
site.
*Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.
*You may shower, and wash surgical incisions with a mild soap 
and warm water. Gently pat the area dry.
*If you have staples, they will be removed at your follow-up 
appointment.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

||startoftext||The patient is a 65-year-old female who presented with abdominal pain. She reported a 2-week history of general malaise, upper respiratory tract infection, and decreased appetite. She also experienced severe abdominal pain, which began while she was sitting on the couch, and had not had a bowel movement or flatus in 2 days. She vomited non-bloody, non-bilious emesis shortly after eating.

The patient has no known allergies or adverse reactions. She has no past medical history, past surgical history, or family history of note.

The patient's physical examination revealed a soft, tender abdomen with focal rebound and guarding. Laboratory results showed elevated white blood cell count, blood urea nitrogen, and creatinine levels, as well as abnormal liver function tests.

The patient underwent a diagnostic laparoscopy, which revealed a gastric perforation. She was converted to an exploratory laparotomy and underwent repair of the perforation with a patch and placement of a Pravena vac.

The patient was prescribed medications at discharge, but the specific medications are not mentioned in the report. ||endoftext||

She has a history of aortic stenosis, patent foramen ovale, coronary artery disease, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and cardiovascular disease. She is allergic to erythromycin base.

The patient's medications at discharge include amiodarone, docusate sodium, aspirin, potassium chloride, atorvastatin, metoprolol tartrate, pantoprazole, furosemide, ciprofloxacin, and warfarin. She was discharged home with service and was advised to follow up with her cardiologist. ||endoftext||

===================

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you in the hospital!

Why was I admitted to the hospital?
-You came to the hospital because you had a perforated colon and 
underwent extensive emergency surgery

What happened while I was admitted to the hospital?
-You had a prolonged and complicated hospital course because of 
your history of lung cancer, severe emphysema, major surgery and 
need for intensive care
-You are required a lot of oxygen and underwent extensive 
testing that revealed blood clots in your lungs and both of your 
arms
-You had several infections in your arms and abdomen that were 
treated with antibiotics
You were evaluated by multiple specialists and palliative care 
specialist
Several family meetings were held with your medical team and 
palliative care specialist that gave you and your family medical 
updates about your conditions and potential care options
You and your family expressed your wish to no longer pursue 
your current plan of care and instead change the focus on 
symptom management which would allow you to spend more time with 
your family and loved ones
-Your lab numbers were closely monitored and you were given 
medications to treat your various medical conditions

What should I do after I leave the hospital?
-You are being discharged with hospice care services that will 
care for your needs closely
-Spend time with your family and loved ones while having your 
symptoms managed

We wish you the very best! 

Your ___ Care Team

target: ||startoftext||Ms. ___ is a 59-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with abdominal pain and a diagnosis of perforated diverticulitis. She has a history of metastatic lung cancer, COPD, Hepatitis C cirrhosis, GERD, fibromyalgia, and opiate use disorder. She underwent a sigmoid colectomy, end descending colostomy, and abdominal washout. During her hospital stay, she developed bilateral upper extremity cellulitis, hyponatremia, and multifactorial hypoxic respiratory failure. She was treated with antibiotics and oxygen therapy. The patient's medications at discharge include ipratropium bromide, lorazepam, oxyCODONE, methadone, levETIRAcetam, and Symbicort. She is being discharged with hospice care and is advised to spend time with her family and loved ones while having her symptoms managed. ||endoftext||

IMAGING:
CXR ___:
Lungs are low volume with diffuse parenchymal opacification 
within the right lung which is new since the prior study and 
could represent pneumonia in the correct clinical setting.  
Follow-up to complete resolution after course of antibiotics in 
___ weeks is recommended.  There are small bilateral effusions 
with mild interstitial edema.  No pneumothorax is seen 

ERCP ___:
The scout film revealed previous stents in place. 
What appeared to be an uncovered metal stent was found in the 
bile duct at the major papilla with a plastic double pigtail 
stent inside.  
After biliary plastic stent removal, the bile duct was deeply 
cannulated with the balloon. 
Given suspicion of debris, the bile duct was swept repeatedly 
with the balloon and copious sludge and stones were extracted 
successfully. 
There was some tissue in-growth seen within the stent. 
A small amount of contrast was injected showing patent bile 
ducts proximally at the CHD and intrahepatic branches. 
___ x 5cm double pigtail plastic and ___ x 7cm biliary plastic 
straight stents were placed into the bile duct to facilitate 
drainage. 
The final occlusion cholangiogram showed no evidence of filling 
defects in the CBD. 
Otherwise normal ercp to third part of the duodenum

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old female with dementia, hypertension, CAD status post 
LAD stent, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, atrial 
fibrillation, ampullary mass requiring ERCP with stenting 
implicated by recurrent cholangitis, who presented with sepsis 
due to cholangitis.

# Acute cholangitis
# Transaminitis: Patient with history of cholangitis and biliary 
stents presented to OSH on ___ with 3 days of fever, RUQ, and 
jaundice. CT a/p and RUQ ultrasound concerning with common bile 
duct and marked
intrahepatic ductal dilatation and gallbladder sludge without 
evidence of cholecystitis. LFTs on admission were elevated (ALT 
111, AST 56, Alk Phos 423), Tbili 7.6. ERCP performed ERCP ___ 
with removal of plastic stent along with sludge and stones.  
LFTs trended down after the intervention.  She was placed on 
cefpodoxime and metronidazole, transitioned from 
piperacillin-tazobactam, for planned seven-day course, to cover 
both cholangitis and possible pneumonia noted below.  The family 
deferred further intevention (cholecystectomy, scheduled repeat 
ERCP) at this time, and will decide based on if patient requires 
a procedure acutely in the future.

# Acute hypoxemic respiratory failure
# Pneumonia: Her exam was most consistent with atelectasis in 
the setting of ICU stay and ERCP procedure. 
CHF and aspiration or other pneumonia are remote considerations 
though she appeared to be improving clinically.  Imaging showed 
infiltrates suspicious for pneumonia, so antibiotics for 
cholangitis were chosen to also cover potential pneumonia, as 
noted above.

#Tachycardia
#Atrial flutter
#Atrial fibrillation: She has a history of atrial fibrillation 
for which she takes Atenolol. Upon arrival to the ED, she was 
tachycardic to 154 and EKG showed atrial flutter.  She was given 
2.5 metoprolol.  Home dose of atenolol was later resumed.

#Diabetes: Previously took Metformin 500mg daily. A1C was 6.0 in 
___, so she was instructed to stop taking the 
Metformin.  She was placed on an insulin sliding scale during 
her admission.

#Hypertension: home atenolol was resumed.

#Papillary neoplasm of ampulla of Vater: Hypoechoic mass in the 
periportal region on Ultrasound. Likely at
least in part causing obstruction leading to cholangitis.  She 
will continue to have outpatient follow-up for this, with PCP 
appointment scheduled.

#CAD s/p LAD stent History of CAD and LAD stent. Takes aspirin 
81 mg daily. EKG on presentation had no ischemic changes and 
troponin was <.01.  Aspirin was resumed.

#Dementia
#Anxiety: History of senile dementia with significant anxiety. 
Takes Seroquel 12.5mg TID, which was resumed.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
==============
# Follow-up: patient will follow up with her PCP.  The family 
deferred further intevention (cholecystectomy, scheduled repeat 
ERCP) at this time, and will decide based on if patient requires 
a procedure acutely in the future.  

# Code status: Full code but only limited trial.  Admitting 
physician discussed this with her son/HCP and he is considering 
making her DNR. It was explained that this would be quite 
reasonable and that this would not have changed the way we 
treated her during this hospital stay. He said would not want 
her to have a prolonged course of CPR but he is not comfortable 
yet with making her DNR.

age: 63. gender: F.  
Name:  ___.              Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___

Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies:

Chief Complaint:
Abdominal Pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Laparoscopic cholecystectomy

 
History of Present Illness:
Mrs. ___ is a ___ F with a PMH significant for gallstones, and
diverticulosis who was transferred to us from OSH with the
diagnosis of gallstone pancreatitis. She has been experiencing
episodic pain across her lower abdomen, mostly centrally but
skewed to the right, for approximately 6 days. The symptoms 
began
after eating fried clam and she initially attributed it to food
poisoning. She described the recurring pain as worsening about 
an
hour after eating and not relieved with antacids. She reports
that black tea has helped symptoms, but that the relief is
temporary. Last night the pain acutely worsened around 2AM and
she experienced dry heaves and sweating and decided to report to
the ED at ___. She reports one episode of vomiting
during the 6 day period, which happened yesterday. It was non
bloody, nonbilious, food predominate vomitus. She has had
periodic nausea, no diarrhea, no distension, no anorexia. No
chest pain/pressure, SOB, or dyspnea. She has never had similar
abdominal pains before. She denied fevers. She has never
experienced abdominal pain before.

non-distended, no hepatosplenomegaly appreciated, no rebound

Pertinent Results:

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the emergency department with abdominal 
pain from an OSH with a known history of gallstones. A consult 
was placed to the acute care surgery team who admitted the 
patient for possible laproscopic cholecystectomy and ERCP. She 
was made NPO and given maintenance fluids.

On hospital day 2, her liver functions tests were globally 
trending down. This indicated possible passing of the gallstone 
through the common bile duct. She also had improvement of her 
pain symtpoms. At this point she was taken to the operating room 
for a laproscopic cholecystectomy which showed a inflamed 
gallbladder which had multiple small stones inside. A JP drain 
was placed as the abdomen had to be irrigated due to some 
contents from the gallbladder spilling into the abdominal 
cavity. The patient tolerated the procedure well and did not 
have any post operative complications.

On hospital day 3, her pain was well controlled. She was 
advanced to a clear diet. Her liver function tests continued to 
trend downward. She was started on a regular diet for dinner 
however took very little in. The surgical site did not appear 
inflamed or infected without signs of erythema or purulent 
discharge. The JP drain continued to drain moderate amount of 
serosanguinous fluid.

On hospital day 4, her pain was again well controlled, her LFTs 
continued to trend down and the patient did not complain of any 
pain. She tolerated regular diet. Since the drain continued to 
output a mild amuont of serosanguinous fluid, she was given 
drain teaching and discharged with the JP drain in place with 
home services to help her care for the drain.

 
Medications on Admission:
Synthroid
Vitamin D
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 500 mg Capsule Sig: ___ Capsules PO Q4H (every 
4 hours) as needed for pain.  
2. Levothyroxine 100 mcg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
3. Oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q4H (every 4 hours) 
as needed for pain.
Disp:*20 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
1. Gallstone pancreatitis.
2. Chronic cholecystitis.

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
ABDOMINAL SURGERY

General discharge instructions
You have had an abdominal operation. This sheet goes over some 
questions and concerns you or your family may have. If you have 
additional questions, or ___ understand something about your 
operation, please call your surgeon.

ACTIVITY:
Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and 
feel you could respond in an emergency.
You may climb stairs.
You may go outside. But avoid traveling long distances until you 
see your surgeon at your next visit.
___ lift more than ___ pounds for 6 weeks. (This is about 
the weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies 
to lifting children, but they may sit on your lap.
You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable. 
You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a 
time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when you 
can resume tub baths or swimming.
Heavy exercise may be started after 6 weeks, but use common 
sense and go slowly at first. 
You may resume sexual activity unless your doctor has told you 
otherwise.

HOW YOU MAY FEEL:
You may feel weak or washed out for 6 weeks. You might want to 
nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you. 
You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your 
throat during surgery.
You might have trouble concentrating or difficulty sleeping. You 
might feel somewhat depressed.
You could have a poor appetite for a while. Food may seem 
unappealing.
All these feelings and reactions are normal and should go away 
in a short time. If they do not, tell your surgeon.

YOUR INCISION:
Your incision may be slightly red around the stitches or 
staples. This is normal.
You may gently wash away dried material around your incision.
Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks. (These are the thin 
paper strips that might be on your incision.) But if they fall 
off before that, its OK.
It is normal to feel a firm ridge along the incision. This will 
go away.
Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area.
Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told 
otherwise.
You may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid staining 
your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe, please call 
your surgeon.
You may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when you may 
resume tub baths or swimming. 
Over the next ___ months, your incision will fade and become 
less prominent.

YOUR BOWELS:
Constipation is a common side effect of medicine such as 
Percocet or codeine. If needed, you may take a stool softener 
(such as Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as Milk 
of Magnesia, 1 tablespoon) twice a day. You can get both of 
these medicines without a prescription.
If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain moving 
the bowels, call your surgeon.
After some operations, diarrhea can occur. If you get diarrhea, 
___ take anti-diarrhea medicines. Drink plenty of fluids and 
see if it goes away. If it does not go away, or is severe and 
you feel ill, please call your surgeon.

PAIN MANAGEMENT:
It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal 
surgery. This pain is often described as soreness.
Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain is 
getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.
You will receive a prescription from your surgeon for pain 
medicine to take by mouth. It is important you take this 
medicine as directed. Do not take it more frequently than 
prescribed. Do not take more medicine at one time than 
prescribed.
Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your 
pain gets too severe.
Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take 
prescription pain medicine. Please ___ take any other pain 
medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your 
surgeon has said it is OK.  
If you are experiencing no pain, it is OK to skip a dose of pain 
medicine. 
To reduce pain, remember to exhale with any exertion or when you 
change positions. 
Remember to use your cough pillow for splinting when you cough 
or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises.
If you experience any of the following, please contact your 
surgeon:
           sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several 
hours 
pain that is getting worse over time
pain accompanied by fever of more than 101
a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain

MEDICATIONS:

Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as 
you did before, unless you have been told differently. 
In some cases, you will have a prescription for antibiotics or 
other medication.
If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to 
take, please call your surgeon.

JP Drain Care:
*Please look at the site every day for signs of infection 
(increased redness or pain, swelling, odor, yellow or bloody 
discharge, warm to touch, fever).
*Maintain suction of the bulb.
*Note color, consistency, and amount of fluid in the drain. Call 
the doctor, ___, or ___ nurse if the amount 
increases significantly or changes in character.
*Be sure to empty the drain frequently. Record the output, if 
instructed to do so.
*You may shower; wash the area gently with warm, soapy water.
*Keep the insertion site clean and dry otherwise.
*Avoid swimming, baths, hot tubs; do not submerge yourself in 
water.
*Make sure to keep the drain attached securely to your body to 
prevent pulling or dislocation.
General Drain Care:
*Please look at the site every day for signs of infection 
(increased redness or pain, swelling, odor, yellow or bloody 
discharge, warm to touch, fever).
*If the drain is connected to a collection container, please 
note color, consistency, and amount of fluid in the drain. Call 
the doctor, ___, or ___ nurse if the amount 
increases significantly or changes in character. Be sure to 
empty the drain frequently. Record the output, if instructed to 
do so.
*Wash the area gently with warm, soapy water.
*Keep the insertion site clean and dry otherwise.
*Avoid swimming, baths, hot tubs; do not submerge yourself in 
water.
*Make sure to keep the drain attached securely to your body to 
prevent pulling or dislocation.

DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your surgeon if you develop:
Worsening abdominal pain
Sharp or severe pain that lasts several hours  
Temperature of 101 degrees or higher
Severe diarrhea
Vomiting
Redness around the incision that is spreading  
Increased swelling around the incision
Excessive bruising around the incision
Cloudy fluid coming from the wound
Bright red blood or foul smelling discharge coming from the 
wound
An increase in drainage from the wound
 
Followup Instructions:
___

She was taken to the operating room for a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, which showed an inflamed gallbladder with multiple small stones inside. The patient tolerated the procedure well and did not have any post-operative complications.

The patient was diagnosed with gallstone pancreatitis and chronic cholecystitis. She was prescribed medications including acetaminophen, levothyroxine, and oxycodone for pain management. The patient was discharged with a JP drain in place and was instructed to follow up with her surgeon.

The patient's discharge condition was good, with a clear and coherent mental status, alert and interactive level of consciousness, and ambulatory status. The patient was advised to follow certain instructions, including avoiding heavy lifting, driving, and traveling long distances, and to resume light exercise and sexual activity after 6 weeks. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
Mrs. ___ was admitted to the inpatient colorectal surgery 
service after laparoscopic colectomy. She is ___ speaking 
but demonstrated basic ___ understanding and was seen by 
interpretive services with the nursing staff. She took in clear 
liquids on post-operative day one however, in the afternoon

liquids. The foley catheter was removed and she voided without 
issue. She had not passed flatus. She continued intravenous

improved however, not passing flatus. On post-operative day

Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
A polyp of the ascending colon

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital after a Laparoscopic Right 
Colectomy for surgical management of your polyp. You have 
recovered from this procedure well and you are now ready to 
return home. Samples of tissue were taken and this tissue has 
been sent to the pathology department for analysis. You will 
receive these pathology results at your follow-up appointment. 
If there is an urgent need for the surgeon to contact you 
regarding these results they will contact you before this time. 
You have tolerated a regular diet, are passing gas and your pain 
is controlled with pain medications by mouth. You may return 
home to finish your recovery.  
 
Please monitor your bowel function closely. You may or may not 
have had a bowel movement prior to your discharge which is 
acceptable, however it is important that you have a bowel 
movement in the next ___ days. After anesthesia it is not 
uncommon for patients to have some decrease in bowel function 
but you should not have prolonged constipation. Some loose stool 
and passing of small amounts of dark, old appearing blood are 
expected. However, if you notice that you are passing bright red 
blood with bowel movements or having loose stool without 
improvement please call the office or go to the emergency room 
if the symptoms are severe. If you are taking narcotic pain 
medications there is a risk that you will have some 
constipation. Please take an over the counter stool softener 
such as Colace, and if the symptoms do not improve call the 
office.

If you have any of the following symptoms please call the office 
for advice ___: 
fever greater than 101.5
increasing abdominal distension
increasing abdominal pain 
nausea/vomiting
inability to tolerate food or liquids
prolonged loose stool
extended constipation  
inability to urinate

Incisions:
You have ___ laparoscopic surgical incisions on your abdomen 
which are closed with internal sutures. These are healing well 
however it is important that you monitor these areas for signs 
and symptoms of infection including: increasing redness of the 
incision lines, white/green/yellow/malodorous drainage, 
increased pain at the incision, increased warmth of the skin at 
the incision, or swelling of the area.

You may shower; pat the incisions dry with a towel, do not rub. 
The small incisions may be left open to the air. If closed with 
steri-strips (little white adhesive strips), these will fall off 
over time, please do not remove them. Please no baths or 
swimming until cleared by the surgical team. 

Pain
It is expected that you will have pain after surgery and this 
pain will gradually improved over the first week or so you are 
home. You will especially have pain when changing positions and 
with movement. You should continue to take 2 Extra Strength 
Tylenol (___) for pain every 8 hours around the clock and you 
may also take Advil (Ibuprofen) 600mg every hours for 7 days. 
Please do not take more than 3000mg of Tylenol in 24 hours or 
any other medications that contain Tylenol such as cold 
medication. Do not drink alcohol while or Tylenol. Please take 
Advil with food. If these medications are not controlling your 
pain to a point where you can ambulate and preform minor tasks, 
you should take a dose of the narcotic pain medication 
Oxycodone. Please take this only if needed for pain. Do not take 
with any other sedating medications or alcohol. Do not drive a 
car if taking narcotic pain medications. 

Activity
You may feel weak or "washed out" for up to 6 weeks after 
surgery. No heavy lifting greater than a gallon of milk for 3 
weeks. You may climb stairs. You may go outside and walk, but 
avoid traveling long distances until you speak with your 
surgical team at your first follow-up visit. Your surgical team 
will clear you for heavier exercise and activity as the observe 
your progress at your follow-up appointment. You should only 
drive a car on your own if you are off narcotic pain medications 
and feel as if your reaction time is back to normal so you can 
react appropriately while driving. 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Discharge Instructions

Surgery

should be avoided for ten (10) days.

at your own pace. ___ try to do too much too soon.

· Do not go swimming or submerge yourself in water for fourteen 
(14) days after your procedure.

· Do not get your incision wet in the shower until your sutures 
are removed.

Medications

· If you were on a medication such as Coumadin (Warfarin), or 
Plavix (Clopidogrel), or Aspirin, do not take this until cleared 
by your Neurosurgeon.

you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.

eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics (prescription 
pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool softener.

site.

· Extreme sleepiness

· Severe headaches not relieved by pain relievers

· Seizures

· Any new problems with your vision or ability to speak

· Weakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or leg

Normal heart, lungs, hila, mediastinum and pleural surfaces. No

pneumonia or CHF. 
.

The left atrium is mildly dilated. No atrial septal defect is 
seen by 2D or color Doppler. There is mild symmetric left

thrombi are seen in the left ventricle. There is no ventricular

No evidence of deep venous thrombosis in right or left lower

Change for 6 ___ XB3 guide.  The initial plan was to pass the

wall motion abnormalities. However, he was noted to have a 
patent formane ovale.  Given absence of atherosclerotic disease,

history of prostate cancer, prothrombotic state. LENIs were

He has a history of prostate cancer, treated with radiation therapy, and no other significant past medical history. He is allergic to Gadolinium-containing agents. 

The patient underwent cardiac catheterization, which showed a total occlusion of the distal left anterior descending (LAD) artery. An attempt was made to open the lesion, but it was not successful, and the patient was treated medically to avoid a potential procedural complication. 

At discharge, the patient's vital signs were stable, and he was prescribed medications, including aspirin, clopidogrel, and heparin. His physical examination was normal, with no signs of cardiac failure or respiratory distress. 

Laboratory results showed elevated troponin levels, indicating cardiac damage, but his kidney and liver function tests were normal. His electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-segment elevation in leads I, aVL, V4-6, consistent with a STEMI. 

The patient's chest X-ray and echocardiogram showed normal heart and lung structures, with no evidence of pneumonia or congestive heart failure. ||endoftext||

Discharge Instructions:
INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
-Touchdown weightbearing left lower extremity

MEDICATIONS:
  1)  Take Tylenol ___ every 6 hours around the clock. This is 
an over the counter medication.
  2)  Add oxycodone as needed for increased pain. Aim to wean 
off this medication in 1 week or sooner.  This is an example on 
how to wean down:
Take 1 tablet every 3 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 4 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 6 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 8 hours as needed x 2 days, 
then 1 tablet every 12 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every before bedtime as needed x 1 day.  
Then continue with Tylenol for pain.
  3)  Do not stop the Tylenol until you are off of the narcotic 
medication.
  4)  Per state regulations, we are limited in the amount of 
narcotics we can prescribe. If you require more, you must 
contact the office to set up an appointment because we cannot 
refill this type of pain medication over the phone. 
  5)  Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you 
should drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and continue 
following the bowel regimen as stated on your medication 
prescription list. These meds (senna, colace, miralax) are over 
the counter and may be obtained at any pharmacy.
  6)  Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
  7)  Please take all medications as prescribed by your 
physicians at discharge.
  8)  Continue all home medications unless specifically 
instructed to stop by your surgeon.
      
ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please continue to take the dabigatran daily.  Continue to use 
of this medication should be dictated by the patient's primary 
care provider.

Discharge Diagnosis:
sternal wound infection

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Sternal Precautions

Weekly labs:
laboratory monitoring required
Creat, bun, T bili, Alt, Ast, Alk ph, wbc, Hct/Hgb

Personal Care:
1. Remove dressings and discard. Dressings may be replaced as 
needed. Use tape sparingly.
2. Clean around the drain site(s), where the tubing exits the 
skin, with hydrogen peroxide.
3. Strip drain tubing, empty bulb(s), and record output(s) ___ 
times per day.
4. A written record of the daily output from each drain should 
be brought to every follow-up appointment. your drains will be 
removed as soon as possible when the daily output tapers off to 
an acceptable amount.
5. You may shower daily, cover the wound and drain with seran 
wrap. shower with assistance as needed.
8. The Dermabond skin glue will begin to flake off in about ___ 
days.
9. No pressure on your chest or abdomen
10. Okay to shower, but no baths until after directed by your 
surgeon
.
Activity:
1. You may resume your regular diet.  Avoid caffeine and 
chocolate.
2. DO NOT drive for 3 weeks.
3. Sternal precautions
4. DO NOT lift anything heavier than 5 pounds or engage in 
strenuous activity for 6 weeks following surgery.
5. Please perform the occupational/physical therapy exercises as 
instructed.
.
Medications:
1. Resume your regular medications unless instructed otherwise 
and take any new meds as ordered .
2. No NSAIDs for one week. You may resume your baby aspirin 
seven days after discharge from the hospital.
3. You may take your prescribed pain medication for moderate to 
severe pain.  You may switch to Tylenol or Extra Strength 
Tylenol for mild pain as directed on the packaging.  Please note 
that Percocet and Vicodin have Tylenol as an active ingredient 
so do not take these meds with additional Tylenol.
4. Take prescription pain medications for pain not relieved by 
tylenol.
5. Take your antibiotic as prescribed.
6. Take Colace, 100 mg by mouth 2 times per day, while taking 
the prescription pain medication. You may use a different 
over-the-counter stool softerner if you wish.
7. Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking any 
narcotic pain medication. You may have constipation when taking 
narcotic pain medications (oxycodone, percocet, vicodin, 
hydrocodone, dilaudid, etc.); you should continue drinking 
fluids, you may take stool softeners, and should eat foods that 
are high in fiber.
.
Call the office IMMEDIATELY if you have any of the following:
1. Signs of infection: fever with chills, increased redness, 
welling, warmth or tenderness at the surgical site, or unusual 
drainage from the incision(s).
2. A large amount of bleeding from the incision(s) or drain(s).
3. Fever greater than 101.5 oF
4. Severe pain NOT relieved by your medication.
.
Return to the ER if: 
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications. 
* If you have shaking chills, fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38 (C) degrees, increased redness,swelling or 
discharge from incision, chest pain, shortness of breath, or 
anything else that is troubling you.
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you.
.
DRAIN DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS
You are being discharged with drains in place. Drain care is a 
clean procedure. Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and warm 
water before performing drain care. Perform drainage care twice 
a day. Try to empty the drain and strip the drain at the same 
time each day. Pull the stopper out of the drainage bottle and 
empty the drainage fluid into the measuring cup. Record the 
amount of drainage fluid on the record sheet. Reestablish drain 
suction.

||startoftext||Mrs. [Name], a 72-year-old female, was admitted to the hospital for a sternal wound infection. She had a history of CABGx3 and was previously treated for sternal wound infection with debridement and antibiotics. She was readmitted for upper pole incisional cellulitis and IV antibiotics. A CT scan showed significant inflammation in the manubrial area and poor healing suggestive of early osteomyelitis. She underwent sternal debridement and bilateral upper pectoralis clavicular head muscle advancement flap with removal of 3 sternal wires. She was started on IV nafcillin and ciprofloxacin, and her wound culture came back positive for MSSA. She was discharged on IV nafcillin and close follow-up with Dr. [Attending].

The patient's past medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, chronic renal insufficiency, anemia, obesity, COPD, hypothyroidism, and osteoporosis. She has a history of abdominal surgery for perforated ulcer, right knee surgery, and hysterectomy with bladder resuspension.

The patient's medications at discharge include ezetimibe, levothyroxine, ranitidine, rosuvastatin, aspirin, docusate sodium, magnesium oxide, acetaminophen, lisinopril, amlodipine, clonidine, ipratropium-albuterol, oxycodone, metoprolol tartrate, furosemide, and nafcillin. She is also scheduled for weekly lab work, including Cr, BUN, T bili, Alt, Ast, Alk ph, wbc, Hct/Hgb. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is an ___ F with h/o NSTEMI in ___ s/p cardiac 
catheterization (50% mid-LAD stenosis and 90% RCA stenosis with 
collaterals) without PCI who is transferred from ___ 
___ for cardiac catheterization after presenting with chest 
pain and shortness of breath on exertion, found to have 2 vessel 
dx w/ thrombus in ramus s/p POBA and occluded LCx w/ thrombus 
s/p DES, c/b bradycardia/hypotension requiring pressors/IABP, 
now resolved. 
  
# CAD: Presentation c/w unstable angina, likely explains DOE, 
was found on cardiac catheterization to have LCx/ramus thrombus 
and diffuse RCA disease, s/p POBA to ramus and DES to LCx. 
Procedure was complicated by vagal response requiring 
pressors/atropine/IABP. She was monitored in the CCU overnight 
and then transferred to the floor. At discharge she was 
hemodynamically stable. Her troponin leak was trended to peak 
and was felt to be consistent with post-procedure changes, given 
stable EKG and lack of suggestive symptoms. Her home aspirin was 
continued. She was loaded with Plavix and will require daily 
dual antiplatelet therapy for the next year. Atorvastatin 80mg 
QD was continued. She was started on Carvedilol 3.125 mg BID 
(there was concern that she had some bronchospasm at a higher 
dose, but tolerated this dose well) and her diltiazem was 
discontinued. Her Losartan was switched to Valsartan 160mg QD 
(better outcomes in heart failure). 
 
# Acute on Chronic diastolic heart failure: Likely ischemic 
cardiomyopathy. Appears to have mild systolic/diastolic dysfxn 
per TTE ___, LVEF was 50-55% and there was suggestion of 
impaired filling.   Repeat TTE on ___ showed LVEF 65%, mild 
symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy, impaired relaxation and 
borderline pulm systolic HTN, minimal aortic valve stenosis. She 
appeared euvolemic on exam. Her home lasix was continued. Her 
Losartan was switched to Valsartan 160mg QD (better outcomes in 
heart failure). 
She was maintained on a 2g Na restriction. As above, she was 
switched from diltiazem to Carvedilol.   

# ___: Carries a diagnosis of stage IV CKD, atrophic kidney, 
baseline proteinuria. At ___ her Cr was elevated to 1.4 on 
admission. This trended down, though she did receive >200 cc's 
of contrast at cath. At discharge her Cr was 1.1.
 
# pAF She carries a history of pAF, but is not on 
anticoagulation due to apparent fall risk. CHADS2 is 6 so very 
high risk for stroke. She was monitored on telemetry and was in 
sinus rhythm. As above, she was started on dual antiplatelet 
therapy which she will require for the next year re. DES. 
Anticoagulation should be considered as an outpatient if felt to 
be safe re. fall risk given high stroke risk.     

# Hypertension : BP was reportedly in 180s sytolic at ___ 
___. They were elevated during this admission as well. Her 
BP regimen was adjusted for more optimal control in the setting 
of coronary disease, to carvedilol and Valsartan, as above. BPs 
at discharge was improved to the systolics 140-160s (baseline 
prior to hospitalization had been SBPs in 160-200s).  
 
# S/p TIA: Continued home ASA 325mg, statin daily.  

# NIDDM: Home Januvia was held in favor of gentle Humalog 
insulin SS. At discharge her homes med was restarted.  

# Hyperlipidemia: Home atorvastatin was continued.  
 
# COPD: Continued on albuterol-ipatroprium, Advair (replacement 
for symbicort)
 
# Gout: Continued home allopurinol

Discharge Instructions:
It was a pleasure caring for you at ___. You were admitted 
with chest pain and a drug eluting stent was inserted in one of 
your heart arteries to keep it open and another artery was 
opened with a balloon. It is very important that you take 
aspirin and clopidogrel every day without fail to prevent the 
stent from clotting off and causing another heart attack. Do not 
stop taking aspirin or clopidogrel unless Dr. ___ 
that it is OK. You have been diagnosede with diastolic heart 
failure. This means that your heart is stiff and doesn't pump as 
well as it should and you could retain extra fluid. Weigh 
yourself every morning, call Dr. ___ weight goes up 
more than 3 lbs in 1 day or 5 pounds in 3 days.

||startoftext||The patient is a 75-year-old female who was admitted for a known large hepatic cyst with progressive shortness of breath over the past year. She has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, urinary incontinence, spinal fusion, ovarian cysts, and osteoporosis. She is allergic to Cipro and Macrodantin.

The patient underwent a laparoscopic converted to open hepatic cyst unroofing, cholecystectomy, and repair of diaphragm with Gore-Tex patch, as well as ERCP. The cyst was benign and contained approximately 3 liters of clear fluid. The patient developed a bile leak and pancreatitis post-operatively, which was managed with a biliary stent and conservative treatment.

The patient was prescribed several medications at discharge, including acetaminophen, oxycodone, atenolol, simvastatin, fluticasone-salmeterol, docusate sodium, solifenacin, alendronate, calcium, and multivitamin. She was also advised to follow up with her doctor and to monitor her incision for redness, drainage, or bleeding.

The patient was discharged home with a JP drain still in place and was advised to follow up with her doctor for further treatment and management of her condition. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old man with history of hypertension, CAD s/p DES to LCx 
(___), dyslipidemia, osteoporosis, and chronic renal 
insufficiency who presented from home s/p fall with leukocytosis 
and multifocal infiltrates on CXR found to have aspiration 
pneumonia and severe dysphagia.  
.
#Fall: Patient fell without any prodromal symptoms and ___ 
post-ictal state.  History was most consistent with mechanical 
fall and patient with history of rare falls in past.  ___ 
evidence of ischemic changes or arrhythmia on EKG.  Last echo in 
___ with ___ systolic dysfunction or obstructive pathology.  He 
was not orthostatic on evaluation.   
.  
#Delirium: Patient presented from home after a fall and 
developed delirium while hospitalized.  His delirium was 
initially complicated by severe agitation requiring a 1:1 aide 
___, two point restraints, and occasional anti-psychotics to 
calm him when he became a safety threat. Delirium attributed to 
hospitalization, NSTEMI and pneumonia. Attempted to re-orient 
patient and normalize sleep wake cycle with good success.  His 
delirium was predominantly hypoactive during the last week of 
his admission.  
.
#Dysphagia:  His dysphagia was a chronic problem that was 
acutely worsened by his fall and subsequent delirium.  
Swallowing function extremely poor on video swallow, and he 
continued to aspirate daily.  He was kept NPO on aspiration 
precautions with nutrition via PPN in the hope that his delirium 
would clear and he would regain his strength to swallow back at 
baseline.  He had a repeat video swallow which revealed 
persistent poor swallowing function.  The family decided that 
regardless of the aspiration risk, Dr. ___ want to eat 
and would assume the risk.  They chose a modified diet in order 
to slightly lessen a large aspiration risk.
.
#Pneumonia: Patient with significant leukocytosis with 
neutrophilia and ___ localizing symptoms on admission. Initial 
CXR with multifocal opacities and left pleural effusion 
concerning for pneumonia but ___ new cough, SOB, or fevers at 
home. ___ recent hospitalizations. Received a dose of 
levofloxacin in the ED. Levofloxacin was discontinued as it was 
not felt that patient had a clinical pneumonia, but more likely 
an asiration pneumonitis (white count normalized overnight). 
However, when patient developed a new oxygen requirement in the 
setting of delirium concern for a developing infectious process 
increased and he was started on vanco/CTX/flagly to cover HCAP 
and aspiration pneumonia. Patient triggered several times for 
hypoxia which was felt secondary to poor clearance of secretions 
and mucus plugging. He received chest ___, mucomyst nebs, 
oropharynx suctioning, and humidified supplemental oxygen.  He 
continued to aspirate during his hospital course with transient 
desaturations.
.
#Pleural effusions: His course was also complicated by pleural 
effusions necessitating right thoracentesis of 900 cc on ___ and 
left thoracentesis of 1.4 L on ___.  Pleural fluid cytology was 
negative for malignant cells. 
.  
#NSTEMI: Patient with history of CAD s/p DES to left cx in ___ 
for 70% lesion. Reported a single episode of chest pain the 
night prior to admission which was short lived and self 
resolved. Reported that he typically gets it once a week. 
Troponins were initially checked and elevated - attributed to 
underlying chronic renal insufficiency. CK/MB flat. In the 
setting patient's acute change in mental status another set of 
enzymes were checked and these ended up initially peaking 
(troponin at 0.50, CKMB 25). Cardiology was consulted and felt 
patient's symptoms were most likely related to demand ischemia 
in the setting of underlying pulmonary pathology and agitation. 
He was given aspirin (PO or PR) but further anticoagulation was 
not started. Echocardiogram was of poor quality but show ___ 
major wall motion abnormalities.  Statin was transiently held 
given patient's aspiration risk and NPO status.  Troponin was 
found to continue to rise to 1.28 ___K-MB and CK 
confirming prior event.
.  
#Chronic renal insufficiency: Baseline creatinine of 1.7. 
Patient trended down to 1.4 during hospitalization as he was 
given PPN and IV fluids. 
.  
#Hypertension: Intermittently hypertensive when agitated.  He 
was continued on home lisinopril when taking POs. 
.
#Enterococcus in Urine: Bland UA but enterococcus (10K-100K) on 
culture. This was felt to be a sign of colonization rather than 
acute infection and thus patient was not treated for UTI. 
.  
#BPH: ___ active issues. Continued home finasteride.   
.  
#Anemia: Chronic in nature. Patient at baseline. ___ signs of 
active bleeding.   
.  
#Osteoporosis: He was followed by Dr. ___ was on 
Actonel as an outpatient. Next BMD scan was due on ___.  ___ 
fractures on CT head or spine, so he was continued outpatient 
calcium and vitamin D.
.
#Code Status: The patient was full code at the beginning of his 
admission, however, his HCP changed it to DNR/DNI prior to the 
end of his admission.  We had a series of family meetings during 
this admission.  This decision was made in accordance with what 
his wife deemed his goals of care: to be home and to avoid tubes 
and drains.  He was discharged home and the family chose to 
enroll him in hospice care.  He was discharged on a modified 
diet and his family understood that he had a 100% chance of 
repeat aspiration, and that it was impossible to predict when he 
would have a significant aspiration.  They signed the DNR/DNI 
forms, and will call the hospice nurse should he have a 
recurrent event.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Dr. ___,

___ were admitted to the ___ after a fall. CT of your head and 
neck showed ___ fractures or bleeding. Your CXR showed some

some medications to calm ___ down. ___ had improved by the time

if ___ eat.  In accordance with your wishes though, ___ have

of aspiration although not eliminate it.  ___ have chosen to

delivered to your home.

target:
||startoftext||The patient is a 91-year-old male who presented to the emergency department after falling at home. He reported a mild episode of chest tightness the previous night, which he attributed to gas pain. He has a history of coronary artery disease, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease. On admission, his physical examination revealed a small abrasion on his head, poor inspiratory effort, and decreased breath sounds in his left lung base. Laboratory results showed leukocytosis, and a chest X-ray was concerning for multifocal pneumonia with bilateral pleural effusions.

The patient underwent thoracentesis on two occasions and was prescribed levofloxacin and tetanus vaccination. He was also given 1 liter of normal saline and had a CT scan of his spine, which showed moderate central spinal canal narrowing at C3-C4. He was discharged with a diagnosis of pneumonia and bilateral pleural effusions.

The patient's medications at discharge included levofloxacin, tetanus vaccination, and unspecified medications. He had a history of allergies to sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the ___ Spine Surgery Service on 
___ and taken to the Operating Room for L3-S1 interbody 
fusion through an anterior approach. Please refer to the 
dictated operative note for further details. The surgery was 
without complication and the patient was transferred to the PACU 
in a stable condition. TEDs/pnemoboots were used for 
postoperative DVT prophylaxis. Intravenous antibiotics were 
given per standard protocol. Initial postop pain was controlled 
with a PCA. On HD#2 she returned to the operating room for a 
scheduled T12-L3 decompression with PSIF as part of a staged 
2-part procedure. Please refer to the dictated operative note 
for further details. The second surgery was also without 
complication and the patient was transferred to the PACU in a 
stable condition. Postoperative HCT was stable. On HD#3 she 
returned for a scheduled T10-S1 posterior fusion with 
instrumentation.  A bupivicaine epidural pain catheter placed at 
the time of the posterior surgery remained in place until postop 
day one. 
She developed a post-operative ileus and an NG tube was placed.  
The ileuse was slowly resolving and NG tube was removed with 
diet advanced.  
She developed acute distension and was transferred to the TICU 
for monitoring. There, an NG tube was placed and her abdomen was 
decompressed.  CT scan showed no sign of blockage.
She was subsequently transferred out of the TICU and monitored.
She was kept NPO until bowel function returned then diet was 
advanced as tolerated. The patient was transitioned to oral pain 
medication when tolerating PO diet. Foley remained in place due 
to post-op urinary incontenance.  This will be managed by her 
PCP. She was fitted with a TLSO brace for ambulation. Physical 
therapy was consulted for mobilization OOB to ambulate. Hospital 
course was otherwise unremarkable. On the day of discharge the 
patient was afebrile with stable vital signs, comfortable on 
oral pain control and tolerating a regular diet.

Discharge Instructions:
You have undergone the following operation: ANTERIOR/POSTERIOR 
Thoracolumbar Decompression With Fusion
 

 
Immediately after the operation:
 

 
-Activity: You should not lift anything greater than 10 lbs for 
2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do not sit or stand 
more than ~45 minutes without getting up and walking around.
 

 
-Rehabilitation/ Physical Therapy: 
 
o2-3 times a day you should go for a walk for ___ minutes as 
part of your recovery. You can walk as much as you can tolerate. 

 
oLimit any kind of lifting.
 

 
-Diet: Eat a normal healthy diet. You may have some constipation 
after surgery. You have been given medication to help with this 
issue.
 

 
-Brace: You have been given a brace. This brace is to be worn 
when you are walking. You may take it off when sitting in a 
chair or while lying in bed.
 

 
-Wound Care: Remove the dressing in 2 days. If the incision is 
draining cover it with a new sterile dressing. If it is dry then 
you can leave the incision open to the air. Once the incision is 
completely dry (usually ___ days after the operation) you may 
take a shower. Do not soak the incision in a bath or pool. If 
the incision starts draining at anytime after surgery, do not 
get the incision wet. Cover it with a sterile dressing. Call the 
office. 
 

 
-You should resume taking your normal ___ medications. No 
NSAIDs.
 

 
-You have also been given Additional Medications to control your 
pain. Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic 
prescriptions, so please plan ahead. You can either have them 
mailed to your ___ or pick them up at the clinic located on 
___ 2. We are not allowed to call in or fax narcotic 
prescriptions (oxycontin, oxycodone, percocet) to your pharmacy. 
In addition, we are only allowed to write for pain medications 
for 90 days from the date of surgery.
 

 
Please call the office if you have a fever>101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit and/or drainage from your wound.
 

Physical Therapy:
Activity:   Activity:  Ambulate with brace

Treatment Frequency:
Please perform leg bag teaching.  Inspect the incision for 
drainage daily.
