||startoftext||The patient is a 59-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital for surgical intervention due to a long history of scoliosis. She presented with back pain and had previously attempted conservative treatment without success. The patient has a history of HLD, GERD, esophagus, asthma, migraines, scoliosis, anxiety, and mitral valve prolapse. She is allergic to Percocdan and nylon sutures.

The patient underwent three surgeries: L3-S1 anterior fusion, anterior fusion and decompression of T12-L3, and posterior decompression and fusion T9-S1 with instrumentation and bone graft. She developed a post-operative ileus and was treated with an NG tube and diet advancement. She also experienced acute distension and was transferred to the TICU for monitoring.

The patient was prescribed several medications at discharge, including oxycodone for pain management. She was advised to follow a normal healthy diet, take medication for constipation, and wear a TLSO brace for ambulation. She was also instructed to limit lifting, follow wound care instructions, and attend physical therapy sessions.

The patient's discharge diagnosis includes scoliosis, urinary incontinence, post-op ileus, and acute post-op blood loss anemia. Her discharge condition is good, and she was discharged with service. ||endoftext||

Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man with a history of CML status

per infectious disease recommendations. The pt was treated with 
a total 14-day course and on discharge he was able to breathe 
comfortably on room air and did not have any oxygen 
desaturations on ambulation.

He has a history of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and has undergone an allogeneic stem cell transplant. He was diagnosed with RSV bronchiolitis and later developed hospital-acquired pneumonia. He was treated with antibiotics and bronchodilators, and his oxygen saturation improved. He also developed a diffuse morbilloform eruption attributed to Cefepime, which was changed to Linezolid, Aztreonam, Cipro, and Flagyl.

The patient has a history of past medical conditions, including acute graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) and cardiomyopathy. He is currently taking immunosuppressive medications, including prednisone, Cellcept, and Neoral, as well as prophylactic medications such as acyclovir and posaconazole.

The patient's physical examination revealed a temperature of 102°F, blood pressure of 100/72 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. His lungs were clear, and his heart was normal. His abdomen was soft, and his extremities were normal.

The patient's laboratory results showed a white blood cell count of 10.2, hemoglobin of 13.5, and platelet count of 275. His liver function tests were normal, and his kidney function tests were slightly elevated.

The patient was discharged on a regimen of medications, including acyclovir, cyclosporine, posaconazole, folic acid, lorazepam, mycophenolate mofetil, omeprazole, ursodiol, ascorbic acid, calcium carbonate, cholecalciferol, magnesium oxide, multivitamin, and dexamethasone. ||endoftext||

She also endorses increased lethargy, fatigue, and sleepiness

more confused recently, not recounting recent events and has

Brief Hospital Course:
___ female with severe COPD on 2L home oxygen, chronic 
pseudotumor cerebri, with underlying chronic hypoxia, presents 
from OSH with hypoxia and headaches here for ___ guided lumbar 
puncture for therapeutic drainage.  
.  
#Hypoxia: Upon admission, the patient was noted to have O2 sats 
in the mid-80s on 4L. Her CXR demonstrated evidence of mild CHF 
and she was diuresed with her home dose of lasix and admitted to 
the MICU for oxygen monitoring. Her acetazolamide was held given 
its potential to exacerbate her hypercarbia. She maintained her 
oxygen saturations and was transferred to the floor where her 
oxygen was weaned to 4L while being treated with her home 
regimen of nebulizers and Spiriva for her history of COPD. Given 
that she had not formally seen a pulmonologist for the workup of 
her hypoxia, she was setup with outpatient follow-up with ___ 
Pulmonary at discharge. It was also felt that the patient likely 
has obstructive sleep apnea given her body habitus, or even some 
hypoventilation syndrome. Given the possible complexity of her 
sleep-breathing patterns, Sleep Medicine recommended that the 
patient follow-up with them in clinic as well, to discuss Sleep 
Study and CPAP/BiPAP.   
.
#Pseudotumor cerebri: Upon admission, the patient complained of 
headaches that were consistent with her history of pseudotumor 
cerebri that was subsequently confirmed on a head-CT. Her 
acetazolamide was held given concern for exacerbating her 
hypercarbia. Throughout her admission, her headaches were stable 
without any visual symptoms and appropriately controlled with 
tylenol and oxycodone. Her aspirin and plavix were held 
(patient's husband reported that he had not given these to her 
X2 weeks given her somnolence on pain meds for her headaches). 
She subsequently received an ___ guided therapeutic LP (___) 
and tolerated it well. Her headaches resolved following her LP 
and aspirin and plavix were restarted. Per the patient, she 
often can go months to years after a therapeutic LP without 
symptoms or need for retapping (last LP in ___. 
.
#Bradycardia: Prior to transfer from the MICU, the patient was 
noted to have HRs in the 40-50s which continued while on the 
floor. She was asymptomatic, and her EKG was notable for sinus 
bradycardia with no conduction defects.  Her metoprolol dose was 
adjusted and her HR increased to the ___ with activity.  She was 
discharged on a lower dose of metoprolol.
.
Inactive Issues:
.
#Eye Crusting: Upon admission, the patient was noted to have 
mild crusting of her left eyelid without any evidence of 
conjunctivitis or blepheritis. She was continued on her home 
blephamide cream and her crusting improved over the course of 
her hospitalization
.  
#CAD and history of MI: During her hospitalization, the patient 
acknowledged some chest heaviness without radiation, dyspnea, 
nausea, or paresthesias that resolved within minutes. Her EKG 
was without ST/T changes and her cardiac enzymes were normal. 
She had no subsequent episodes of chest pain throughout her 
hospitalization and was continued on her home regimen of 
lipitor, metoprolol and imdur. According to records obtained 
from ___ where the patient underwent cardiac 
catheterization in ___, the patient has three Cypher (DES) 
stents in her LAD distribution. 
.

appointment with ___ Sleep Medicine

target: ||startoftext||The patient is a 52-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with hypoxia and headaches. She has a history of severe COPD, pseudotumor cerebri, and myocardial infarction with three stents placed. She is also morbidly obese and has diabetes mellitus type 2. The patient's allergies include penicillins, OxyContin, Vicodin, and MS. She was admitted to the MICU for oxygen monitoring and treatment of her hypoxia and headaches. During her admission, she underwent an interventional radiology-guided lumbar puncture and was treated with nebulizers, steroids, and antibiotics. The patient's oxygen saturation improved, and she was eventually transferred to the floor for further treatment. At discharge, she was prescribed medications including acetazolamide, oxycodone, and tylenol, and was scheduled for follow-up appointments with a pulmonologist and sleep medicine specialist. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
 ___ with a history of MI (___), CHF (EF 55-60% ___, GI bleed 
s/p ileostomy c/b bowel obstructions, CKD who was transferred to 
___ from OSH for L sided pneumonia and pleural effusion, 
admitted to MICU for medical management of left pleural 
effusion, hypotension (low at baseline), ___ on CKD, and 
electrolyte derangement. 
 
# L Pleural Effusion - Etiology was considered in setting of 
pneumonia (leukocytosis with left shift, cough, though afebrile) 
vs. malignancy vs. CHF exacerbation. Pleural fluid studies were 
consistent with exudative effusion (elevated LDH, fluid/serum 
protein .46), making infectious etiology most likely. Patient 
initially received CTX/Azithro at OSH. Given GI symptoms in 
setting of slight hyponatremia, we sent Legionella antigen, 
which were negative. In the MICU we continued CTX and 
Azithromycin. CT chest showed loculated non hemorrhagic 
effusions. No evidence of occult malignancy. Pleural fluid was 
sent for cytology which was negative. 

# Shock - Patient was initially hypotensive to SBPs ___. 
Distributive is most likely in setting of pulmonary infection. 
Lactate was normal. Pressures become stable with SBPs ___ 
s/p Albumin 25g IV in the ED. Cardiogenic etiology is less 
likely given normal TTE in ___. We continued to treat infection 
as described above.   
 
# Congestive Heart Failure - EF 55-60% on TTE in ___. Patient 
has been taking Lasix 40mg PO TID at home. BNP 28329 (patient 
does have CKD, 797 in ___. She was volume overloaded on exam 
(marked JVD and acute onset ___. Possibly exacerbated in the 
setting of paroxysmal afib. Diuresis was held due to hypotension 
in the MICU; however, on the floor she was digressed with 40 mg 
IV lasix for a total of 9L net negative for LOS. Her lasix was 
switched to 30 mg of Torsemide on discharge for better 
absorption. 

#Pre renal ___: On admission Creatinine elevated to 2.5. On 
___ it was 1.03, though elevated to 3.3 in ___. Likely 
cardiorenal physiology in setting of CHF and RAS (BUN/Cr 30). 
C/b hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia and ACD. She 
was diuresed and her Cr improved to normal with discharge of 
0.9. She did have persistently low bicarb that improved with 
supplementation. 

# Atrial fibrillation - CHA2DS2-VASc 5 - Patient managed on 
nadolol at home. She had been started on Eliquis ___, but 
discontinued due to GIB. Patient reports increased palpitations 
over the past several days, no dizziness/lightheadedness. 
Metoprolol tartrate 6.25 IV q6h was started in the ICU and her 
metoprolol was switched to PO and uptitrated for better rate 
control. Free T4 and T3 were WNL. She was discharged on 150 XL 
of metoprolol. 
  
#Severe Malnutrition - Pt weighs 99 lbs BMI 13. Based on her 
height, ideal weight is 160 lbs. Chronically underweight and no 
evidence of underlying psychiatric illness and felt to be ___ to 
ABD pain and hyperthyroidism She's had multiple bowel surgeries 
and malabsorption is possible and fecal fat studies are pending 
at time of discharge. Celiac's ruled out. Vitamin D 27 and she 
was started on 1/weekly supplementation w/50k. B12/Folate WNL. 
She should continue with Carnation or Ensure shakes TID. 

 # Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis - Pure AG metabolic acidosis 
most likely due to uremia. Another possible cause was increased 
acetaminophen ingestion in setting of pain (oxoproline). She was 
not compensating appropriately (pCO2 should be ___, likely 
___ hypoventilation in setting of marked effusion and breathing 
limited by pain (thus also some component of respiratory 
acidosis). Patient received bicarbonate in the ED. Acidosis 
began to improve with improvement in her shock state.  

 # Hyperkalemia - Likely in setting of CKD, exacerbated by 
acidosis. Patient was given Insulin/Dextrose and Calcium 
Gluconate in ED for K of 5.9. Patient received an EKG without 
peaked T waves. Her potassium began to trend toward normal.   

 # Hyperphosphatemia - Chronic issue in setting of CKD, patient 
also has hypocalcemia.  

 # Hypocalcemia - Corrected Ca 7.6. Secondary PTH likely given 
CKD. In setting of hyperkalemia/hypocalcemia and worsening renal 
function. 
 
 # Hyperthyroidism - Patient reportedly had thyroid US within 
last 6mo. R>L thyroid enlargement, which she says has been 
increasing since US.  Patient was continued on her home 
methimazole of 20 mg. 
 
 # Anemia - Patient has known CKD. There may be some component 
of nutritional deficiency, poor PO intake, s/p ileostomy. 
Patient did not require transfusion in the unit or on the 
medicine floor.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___, 

You came to us with shortness of breath and we found that you 
likely had a pneumonia and a loculated pleural effusion. Our 
Thoracic surgeons drained the fluid and added a chest tube which 
drained the remaining fluid. A repeat CT shows no pneumonia or 
signs of malignancy. We had endocrine see you who recommended 
seeing an ophthalmologist for your hyperthyroidism. We removed 
nearly 8 liters of fluid from you for a heart failure 
exacerbation. We are changing your Lasix to Toresemide which is 
better absorbed. We are discharging you on 30 mg daily. Please 
follow up with your cardiologist for labs and adjustment of the 
dose. 

It was a pleasure taking care of you and we wish you the best!
Your ___ Team.

||startoftext||The patient is a 64-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with shortness of breath and chest pain. She has a history of myocardial infarction, congestive heart failure, atrial fibrillation, hyperthyroidism, gastrointestinal bleeding, and chronic kidney disease. She is allergic to non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). 

The patient's presenting symptoms included worsening left-sided pleuritic chest pain and dyspnea, as well as increasing bilateral leg edema. She also experienced nausea, vomiting, and decreased oral intake. 

The patient underwent a chest tube and thoracentesis, which resulted in significant improvement in her dyspnea and oxygen saturation. She was diagnosed with pneumonia and pleural effusion, and was treated with antibiotics and other medications. 

At discharge, the patient's vital signs were stable, and she was able to breathe comfortably. She was advised to continue taking her medications as prescribed and to follow up with her primary care physician for further evaluation and treatment. ||endoftext||

.

Brief Hospital Course:
PRIMARY REASON FOR ADMISSION: 
___ F with multiple medical problems and recent complaints of 
worsening dyspnea on exertion who presents for planned CCU 
admission for aspirin desensitization prior to cardiac 
catheterization for further work up of DOE.  
.
ACTIVE DIAGNOSES:
.
# Diastolic CHF: Pt has diastolic CHF based on cardiac cath, and 
given the absence of coronary disease, this is likely the cause 
of her exertional dyspnea. This is consistent with her 
longstanding history of HTN. She was diuresed with IV lasix and 
her home lasix was increased to 20mg po daily. She was also 
started on metoprolol succinate 50 mg qday and lisinopril 2.5mg 
po qday. At the time of discharge she was asymptomatic and her 
weight was 64.5kg.  
.
# Pulmonary HTN: Pt has significant pulmonary HTN (PA pressure 
52/___) based on cardiac cath, and this is likely also 
contributing to exertional dyspnea. This is likely ___ her left 
sided diastolic CHF, but given history of bronchiectasis, cannot 
rule out a primary pulmonary component to her elevated PA 
pressures. She was discarged on ACEI, diuretic and beta blocker 
per above. 
.
# ASA Allergy: Pt underwent successful ASA desensitization. ASA 
reaction is documented as urticaria/angioedema, but during 
desensitization she only experienced pruritis without other 
manifestations of hypersensitivity. She was desensitized per 
___ protocol without indicent and should continue taking ASA 
81 indefinately to prevent recurrence of hypersensitivity.  
.

She has a history of multiple medical problems, including diet-controlled type II diabetes, hypertension, chronic joint pain, and recent visual problems. She has had recent complaints of chest pain and shortness of breath, which have been worsening over time. She underwent right and left cardiac catheterization, which showed mild LVH with preserved ejection fraction. She was diagnosed with coronary artery disease and underwent cardiac catheterization to evaluate for left main disease prior to surgery. At discharge, she was prescribed medications and advised to follow up with her cardiologist.

Relevant past medical history includes spinal stenosis, fibromyalgia/polymyalgia rheumatica, hypertension, osteoarthritis, depression, and s/p bilateral oopherectomy. She has allergies to Aspirin, Ultram, Vioxx, Percocet, Vicodin, and Cephalexin.

The patient's physical examination revealed a slightly distant S1, S2 with no appreciable M/R/G, and no chest wall deformities, scoliosis, or kyphosis. Her abdomen was soft, non-tender, and non-distended, and her extremities showed non-pitting 1+ lower extremity edema, symmetric, and no calf tenderness.

Pertinent lab results include a glucose level of 153* on admission and 133* at discharge, with a normal white blood cell count and platelet count. Her chest X-ray showed lower lung volumes and fullness of indistinct pulmonary vessels consistent with elevated pulmonary venous pressure. ||endoftext||
